Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the parent needs to handle the situation
Situation2: Early in their career, they have not yet saved enough for travel.
Story:
I stood frozen in the small grocery store, my son’s hand still clutching the candy bar he’d tried to slip into his pocket. The shopkeeper’s stern gaze bore into me, and I felt the weight of my responsibility as a parent pressing down. I was supposed to teach him right from wrong, to guide him with patience and discipline, but shame and disappointment tangled in my chest. I wanted to show him compassion, to explain why stealing was wrong, but I also knew I had to be firm.

At the same time, my mind drifted to my own shortcomings. As a Muslim, I was expected to perform Hajj, to fulfill this pillar of my faith. Yet, here I was, still early in my career, barely making ends meet, unable to save enough for the journey. I felt like I was failing in both roles—unable to provide the spiritual example I wanted for my child, unable to meet the expectations of my faith. The pressure to be a good parent and a good Muslim pulled me in opposite directions, and I stood there, heart pounding, unsure of what to do next.
